label: Letter from Gertrude Sanford Legendre, May 11, 1943
description: Letter from Gertrude Legendre to her husband, Sidney Legendre, reflecting on which organization she should join, possibly the Women’s Army Auxiliary Corps (WAACs), as a method of joining him in Hawaii. Gertrude continues in her letter to relay news of their friends and family, speculate over the wonderful summer the children will have at Watch Hill, and lamenting her own wanderlust.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
P.S. Why the change of address? You never mentioned it. I hope I am
right in sending it this way.
M 12
R 5 18 43
May 11th '43
Sidney Darling,
To my delight this morning three letters arrived together in a bunch
from you. April 26th,28th,24th, and May fifth. My I was delighted to get them as it
seemed ages since I had heard from you.
Your description of Easter Sunday, church, the beach, surfboarding,
the blue sky and bluer sea all sounded such heaven. It seems so mean I cant be there
with you to do it all with you and enjoy it together, I always have wanted that life
the most.I have always wanted the florida sunshine and sea, the Antibes bathing, the
shiny green babnana leaves, the coacoanut palms- and now that you are in it for months
on end [I] cant be there beside you to revel in it too. Its sickning and it makes me
so unhappy. It seems so unfair, so mixed up. Other times when you had no work to do
you did not want to go to those sort of places and lie about and do nothing, now you
have a job and you really enjoy the beach life and revel in it. What a real pity it
is [I] cant be doing my job there too instead of in this hellhole.
I cant understand your not be allowed to sencor your own letters. I
thought all intellegence officers could do that. It sounds like school boy stuff
having such red tape and nonsence with grown men in confidential positions whom 
I woul_d immagine would be trusted to the nth degree. Well thats the service for
you!
I was sorry to hear poor old Morris got malaria again. [H]e has never
really been able to throw it off has he. Things like that creep up on you when you
get overtired. You never mentioned your back in these last 4 letters so I immagine
it must be O.K. unless you ruined [it] again when you took that hedder on the coral reef
to avoid the outrigger ---- ?
Your wind channel of an office sounds frightfully typhoonish. I am
surprised airconditioning was not installed,and then have no windows like at the
Pentagon bldg. You must need worlds of paper weights to keep all that mass of
paper under control. Your giant publishing task sound herculanlon and I bet you
will be glad when that is complete and behind you. You must be dead from staying up
so late completeing it. Watch out or you will end up like Morris in bed with a scorcher
or a cold or something. _
If Washington had the setting of Hawaii believe me I could take it.
I would n't mind at all but I assure you this daily grind is to kill you with nothing
but city streets no air and no exercise. I have not played tennis for four months
or golf either, Nothing. Except for those Sunday spurts to Foxcroft I have n't seen
a field or a hill or a garden.I never get in the sun as Sunday is always overcast.
I am confusedabout joining ghe WAAcs as it too will mean a desk job
abroad. I will be in an office where ever I am[,]and I cant make up my mind whether
one spot will be better than an ogher. Its so difficult. If   dont join ofcourse then
my future in the Q bldg is a ceratinty for the duration. That prospect horrifies me.
If I join I may be in the London office which will be equally dreary. I am really
confused. I wonder if you have to be a WAAS even to get to Hawaii? I am told there
is not one WAAC in Hawaii  If I became a WAAC I wonder if anybody out there would
ask for me.
[End Page 1]
2
The only way one gets places is to be asked for. Bruce will ask for me alright but
I am not any too sure I would be any better off[,]thats the hell of it. Only at least
I would n't feel trapped here for the duration. One can get around in a uniform.
My job is good here , and may be I should be sa[t]isfied and keep quiet[,]but you know m e
staying months and months at the same thing in the same way, the old daily grind is
heartbreaking. How I wish [I] had been able to get a field assignement some how. Maybe
David would try and get me one. He is more anxious to give me what I want- a break
so to speak- than any one. Helen is going off to Ireland soon to a Am Legation job
as she is a great Pal of our man out there. This gets her closer to her boys and gives
her a chance to see them[Which is what she wants]. She is in luck. My job here is
so fearfully enormous now [I] have my doubts honestly if and when the alotment comes
through am even going to be allowed to go if I decide Iw ant to. The whole thing
is a mess in my mind. I just DONT KNOW.
I have been told that your suggestion of becomming a secretary-stenographer
would not even get me out of tho U.S.A. All offices are desperate for stenogs and as
soon as you get any sort of rating they clamp on to you and throw you into some Gov.
bldg, like the Army and Navy and thats the last you ever are [h]eard from. Ones chances
of getting sent to Hawaii because you might be needed plays no part. People are forced
to do what they are told. You have no choice. I would be bogged down typing in the
Navy till kingdom come. lou have to actually have pull, be asked for, have a real drag
to get any place. Do you suppose the navy will ever change their rules about men on
shore duty being allowed to send for their wives? that I believe is the only way I    
could get out. Have you heard of anyone arriving out there lately under any pretext?
It all seems too foolish[,]and too childish if you are to be there for the duration
and I am willing to sign up for a job for a year.  I cant see how some can be allowed
out and others not. I wish I knew the formula- if there is one. Believe me I am stumped.
Armant has given up all hope,and Olive tells me she thinks he will work on getting 
somewhere else.Its just a crime all of you did not get mixed up with this.You could
get around and be I think more interested[,]however you cant beat your climate and s_pot
and that ofcourse is alot. Maybe its everything. I a[m]beginning to believe that weeather
and surroundings honestly count the most. Why not settle in Hawaii when the war is
over[?] It would suit me I assure you. Its the top I think. Its got everything
The news is good thats a certainty but we have miles to go yet, and
I am sure it will be tough going too. 
Tony Frissel who is staying with me for a few days while taking
pictures for the WAACS- invited Al Hall and John Mc Clein for dinner last night. We
talked till after eleven o'clock and it was pretty good fun. Tony thinks Al is a o-
charmer. I think he is quite nuts. All I think he has is a good looking face and I
cant get very excited about that when I have the best looking face in the world darling
which is yours. Just a face is not enough. Fortunately you have the works whioh is
the ONE AND ONLY of its kind in the world. What I would give to see you right now.
My its so long since last August. I am getting soft and sloppy looking which drives
me nuts. All my muscles are so soft there just flabby. I do so envy you and Morris
and your streamlined figgures which you can keep taught from that surf borading. I
think there is nothing so disgusting as softpeople and thats me now. Just to get
exercise it might be worth joining thwe WAACS,and getting stretched and drilled abit.
My office has three desks, threesafes, two tables and a coat hanger.
Its the messyest looking room you ever saw. Grim to day the least. Not a speck of air
as its so close to the next building. The room is cluttered with files, stamps, number
machines, typewriters, logs, wastepaper basketsand routing sheets. I had over a thousand
messages to handle yesterday. We stem till seven fifteen which has become usual , and
I must say its not as bad as your midnight hour but its not good either.
I dream at night about what I have been doing all day. Its madning.
[End Page 2]
3
Bo is very well although I see very little of her. Just breakfast - because
at night she is nearly always asleep when I get home. Landnne will be back from school
the last day of May and I draed the ordeal fo firing Melle. June ist. There is going
to be such a scene.
Al is taking Tony out to-night,and I am going to pay my bills,and get to bed
early,and try and make up some sleep. Its a nuisance to pay bills all night as the
desk becomes a night mare by night fall but it must be done.
Miss Finucan writesme very seldom but Henry quite often. Rosa had an operation
and I got the bill yesterday. Its the old story of syphilus that they all have to
such a point that it eventually kills them. She will be better for a while anyhow.
I have had the radio victola sent up that did not work[,]and I am getting it
put into running order. I think it will be nice to have.
Have you read Wilkies book? It has caused a sensation. Why I can not
immagine as it is a simple little travel book of very limited importence or interest.
Its in its fifth printing.
I wrote you in my last letter that Kathrine expected Henry to go overseas
any day. I think he has gone now. She is working hard. I never get up to Andalusia
as it is such a trip on weekends with traveling the way it is. Its exhausting. I would
love to see her though and wishI [I] could manage it. Kathrine to me is the most attractive
woman I know.She has everything, Miss Charlotte runs her a neck it neck second. Those
two have not only all the vitality but to me the outlook, the charm, the gayesty and
the real- stuffings that count. I really admire both of them more than any one else.
I am afraid my stuffings are full of holes and leaks, I feel some times like
a sack of meal. Indisicion is a dredful feeling and I think that is part of my
trouble. I hope it all clears up for me some how. If only your plans had a baring
on mine it would make sense.
[I am home and am writing this after supper as I sit in my dressing gown in the
living room] Miss Evan[s] and I have been talking about summer plans for Watch Hill.
Talking about how Landine is going to react to losing Mademoiselle, how she msut
not be made to stuff when not hungry, how too much time is spent taking naps, how
too much thought is given to her wellfare, her clothes and one thing and a other
Melle, dotes on. It will be an awful wrench but a good one for her and I think
life at the beach this summer will clear everything up and adjust her to Miss Evans
who really is a swell person. The more I see of her the better I like her. I shall
raise her salary to 150 per month. If I thought Darling you wpuld rather I stayed
home with your children [and mine] I would do so chearfully and feel that afterall
there is point to it because Sidney wants it so- if it does not make any difference
why then my own feelings of what G,S,L. wants to do comes into it an dI am all on
the fence. Worlds to conquer type of thing always appeals to me, change, motion,
new possibilities, new heights, etc etc. You know them all. Its my restlessness,
my wander lust, my desire not to stay put forever in the same spot with the same
scene, the same people and the same everything. Perhaps I could do more, be more
useful, go further. On the other hand -Why go anywhere? Why attain anything? Why
not be satisfied, comfortable and content, In England- no eggs, slim rations,
cold weather etc etc. but then you know discomforts dont b[o]g me down really.
Well darl[i]ng I shall not bore you with my problem but I wish I could talk to you,
hear what you think etc. etc. In one of your letters today you thought it was the
right thing Join the WAACS. You however are so,unselfish you might say it to please
me and make me happy if you thought it was what I wanted to hear. I would rather
however know the real you. The real truth, your real feelings. Above all if you 
have any incling of what you might do, or where you might go that to me would t
transend everything[,] because I would die if you come to Washington and I hadgone
to London. Is there a plan for you in the air at all anywhere, any place.?
It is raining torrents outside and my house seems by comparison very
cozy.It would truly be cozy if you and I were to now go upatirs together to bed
and hug [[and] cuddle till morning - My how lovely that would be my darling
I send you all my love [and] a thousand kisses [and] long for the day I
see my sweet Sidney again- Gertie-]
[End Page 3]
